SafetyInspectionBy: San Joaquin County Office of Emergency Services

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: Process Safety Management Standard at 29 CFR 1910.119

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Fresh Start Bakeries uses anhydrous ammonia for process refrigeration.  Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the CalARP program requirements.

This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this updated plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system, as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility.  This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and its processes, and the training that we provide our personnel.   This Plan is updated as required by law.

Our Emergency Action Plan (EAP) details the response this facility will take as a result of an uncontrolled release of ammonia.  The Plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency responders and the contracted refrigeration contractor.  This EAP also includes a specific protocol for responding to an ammonia release and assigns an Emergency Coordinator to implement the response.  All employees at the facility have the following knowledge: 1) general awareness of ammonia at the facility, 2) how to report an ammonia release, 3) where to go when

they are told to evacuate.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan.  

This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Stationary Source

 Fresh Start Bakeries began operating this facility in 1987. The ammonia refrigeration system was originally designed and installed in the same year by Applied Process Cooling Corporation (APCCO) of Modesto, California.  There have been some equipment changes to the refrigeration system since its inception.  The facility is located at 920 North Shaw Road, Stockton, California, on the east side of State Highway 99 and north of State Highway 26 (East Fremont Street).  The immediate area is primarily commercial with some light industrial and residential areas.

Fresh Start Bakeries is a wholesale, single-purpose facility for the Quick Service Restaurant industry.  The Stockton facility produces and freezes approximately 21 million dozen hamburger buns each year.  The plant operates three shifts every day of the year.  Shift hours are:

1st  Shift: 0700 ? 1500 hrs
2nd Shift:1500 ? 2300 hrs
3rd Shift: 2300 ? 0700 hrs

The company history below was excerpted from the company website:

UNITED STATES

Fresh Start Bakeries' history began in the early 1960s with the construction and operation of the first major bakery to serve McDonald's in Southern California.  In 1971, a new plant was built in Southern California in City of Industry, which today remains one of the largest capacity hamburger bun baking facilities in the world

, capable of producing 8,000 dozen hamburger buns per hour and 1,400 dozen English muffins per hour.  In 1969, a plant was built in San Jose to supply Northern California (later replaced with a state-of-the-art facility located in Stockton in 1987).  In 1974, Fresh Start continued its expansion by building a third bakery in Hawaii to serve various customers in the Hawaiian Islands.

In 1984, the company built a single-purpose hamburger bun bakery in Kansas City, Kansas that serves Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Southern Illinois and parts of various other surrounding states.  Today, this facility is a joint venture with Best Harvest Bakeries and qualifies for diversity (minority) supplier status.  The Kansas City plant represented a significant step forward in bakery automation for the hamburger bun baking industry and remains one of the most labor efficient bun bakeries of its size in the United States.

In 1997, Fresh Start Bakeries established a joint venture to build the Tennessee Bun Company (TBC) in Dickson, TN.  TBC is considered one of the most highly automated facilities in the world, baking over 5,000 dozen buns per hour on one line.  In 2001, the partners of TBC expanded their business relationship by equipping an additional production facility in nearby Nashville, TN.  This facility, Nashville Bun Company (NBC), bakes English muffins in a variety of flavors and sizes.  In addition, NBC freezes muffins and buns, and packages them into corrugated boxes for distribution to over 40 states in the U.S., the Caribbean Islands and South America.  These two facilities qualify for minority supplier status.

INTERNATIONAL

The strength of Fresh Start's performance in the United States provided the opportunity to grow internationally.  In 1988, we opened our first international bakeries in Duisburg, Germany and Sao Paulo, Brazil.  The early success of Fresh Start in the international transfer of American baking technology led to additional global opportunities.  We cur

rently operate manufacturing facilities in the following international locations:

1.    Duisburg, Germany
2.    Juiz de For a, Brazil
3.    Sydney, Australia
4.    Warsaw, Poland
5.    Osasco, Brazil
6.    Melbourne, Australia
7.    Malmo, Sweden
8.    Sao Paulo, Brazil
9.    Stockholm, Sweden
10.  Santiago, Chile
11.  Barcelona, Spain
12.  Guatemala City, Guatemala
13.  Madrid, Spain

 The Regulated Substance Handled

The Fresh Start Bakeries facility utilizes approximately 11,300 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia as a heat transfer fluid in the plant refrigeration system.  The system is a two-stage mechanical refrigeration system that provides controlled cooling to the Cool Dock, Blast Freezer, the Ante Room, and the underfloor heat exchanger for the freezer.  A glycol chiller provides cooling for the mixers.  The system operates 24 hours a day each day of the year.

AMMONIA SYSTEM EQUIPMENT

High Stage Screw Compressors
Low Stage Screw Compressors
Evaporative Condenser
Intercooler
Controlled Pressure Receiver
Low Temperature Pump Receiver
Recirculation Pumps
Surge Vessel and Ice Builder
Evaporators
Underfloor Heat Exchanger
Glycol Chiller
Auto Purger
Emergency Refrigerant Control Box
Water Diffusion Tanks

Ammonia sensors are located in strategic locations to alert facility personnel of a system leak.  The attic detector activates the ventilation fans in the attic, while the Engine Room ventilation fan is always operating.  The Engine Room detector will shut down the main liquid feed solenoid in order to stop, or mitigate, a catastrophic release.  Each detector will sound an audible and visual alarm located inside the main facility.

Additional safety systems include:

Pressure relief valves
Compressor control switches
Compressor control panels to shut down the compressor operation if safe operating conditions are exceeded
Liquid level float switches
Ventilation system for continuous ventilation 
Emergency refrigeration control switch for emergency shutdown of the syste

m
PLC for monitoring and control
Fire suppression system
Emergency shower and eyewash station

The system is physically monitored and inspected daily while the system is in operation by trained personnel.  Any deficiencies discovered are corrected promptly via a work order system and CMMS.  Maintenance is performed regularly by a qualified refrigeration contractor, who is contacted in the event of serious deficiencies or abnormal operation.  All maintenance and repair records are kept under the direction of the Chief Engineer.

Designated plant personnel are trained how to perform a total system shutdown in the event of an emergency.  The training includes recognition of system emergency conditions, notification of emergency responders, and the procedures to shutdown the system.  All plant personnel are trained to implement emergency response procedures, including evacuation and notifications, according to the Emergency Action Plan.

Hazards of the ammonia refrigeration process have been evaluated as required to ensure that adequate safeguards are in place to reduce the likelihood or severity of a release.
